text: hi I'm Melissa Clark from the dining
section st. Patrick's Day is just around
the corner and I want to bake something
special for it the question is Irish
soda bread or green bagels
okay so Irish soda bread one but instead
of making one big round loaf I decided
to make buns they're so cute and so easy
to eat in this bowl I've got regular
all-purpose flour I'm gonna add a little
bit of whole wheat flour just for
earthiness some sugar for a slight
sweetness baking soda because you need
baking soda for Irish soda bread
it wouldn't be soda bread baking powder
and salt then just whisk it all up I'm
gonna cut three tablespoons of butter
into the dry ingredients for the exact
recipe go to nytimes.com slash dining to
cut the butter in you could use a food
processor it goes really quickly but
then you have to clean it and it's such
a small amount of butter it's almost
easier to just do it by hand so you
could use a pastry cutter if you have
one it's a great tool or you take two
knives and you just cut the butter just
like this or you could just use your
fingers just smush it together like that
what you want to do is just break up the
pieces of butter with your fingers and
work them into the flour a few little
lumps though are good that's what you
want but not any big chunks now you read
your wet ingredients
I've got buttermilk I'm gonna mix an egg
into the buttermilk and then I'm gonna
pour it into the bowl you just stir it
together until all of the flour is
dampened and it comes together like
dough now I'm going to add two
ingredients which are not strictly
traditional in Ireland but they're
really good I've got currants you could
use raisins just chop them up and
caraway seeds
turn the dough out onto a lightly
floured surface and just press it into a
round about an inch thick this came out
really sticky so I'm going to add a
little bit more flour just so I can work
with it so this is what you want just a
nice round disc I'm gonna cut it into 8
wedges and then roll them up into cute
little buns I'm gonna flour my knife
because this is super sticky dough by
the way if you want to bake the dough
into one big round loaf go ahead
probably take you 40 to 50 minutes in
the oven then just move them on to your
greased baking sheet space them well
apart because they will rise I'm gonna
cut little X's into the tops of each bun
it'll get crispy right where the cut
marks are and you know it looks pretty
then brush them with a little buttermilk
to make them extra golden brown and as a
final garnish I'm gonna dust the tops
with a little bit of flour this is
purely for looks you could skip this
step if you want now I'm going to put
them in a 375-degree oven until they are
brown and gorgeous about 20 to 25
minutes and here you have warm Irish
soda buns you can serve them with corn
beef and cabbage but I'm just gonna
smear them with good Irish butter that's
all I need
you
